string-array.name: sun
string-array.item: The Sun alone contains 99.8% of the total mass in the Solar System
In terms of volume, one million Earths could fit inside the sun
The Sun is travelling at 220 km per second.
The distance between Earth and Sun changes, because the Earth travels on a elliptical orbit path around the Sun.
Temperatures inside the Sun can reach 15 million degrees Celsius.
The Sun, formed about 4.6 billion years ago, is roughly halfway through the most stable part of its life.

string-array.name: mercury
string-array.item: Mercury is 68.861 million kilometers from the sun
Mercury could fit inside Earth 18 times
Mercury’s days are 1408 Earth hours while a year on mercury is only 88 Earth days
Mercury does not have any moons
Mercury is terrestrial, meaning it’s made up of solid Earth like material
Mercury possesses a thin exosphere made up of material blasted off the surface by solar winds and meteoroids
Mercury’s surface temperature ranges from 430ºC to -180ºC
Mercury is the Roman god of commerce, communication and luck. Greek: Hermes

string-array.name: venus
string-array.item: Venus is 107.721 million kilometers away from the sun
Venus is very similar in size to Earth only being 0.866 as much volume as Earth
One Venus day is 116 days and 18 hours on Earth, while one year is only 225 Earth days
Venus lacks any amount of moons
Venus is terrestrial, meaning it’s a rocky planet
Venus’ atmosphere is thick and toxic being filled with carbon dioxide and yellowish clouds of sulfuric acid
The temperature on venus ranges from 438ºC to 482ºC
Venus is the Roman goddess of love, beauty, and desire. Greek: Aphrodite

string-array.name: earth
string-array.item: Earth is 147.976 million kilometers from the sun
The Earth has a diameter of 12,742 kilometers
One day on Earth is 24hrs while a year is 365 days
Earth has one moon, the moon
Earth is terrestrial
Earth’s atmosphere is 78% Nitrogen, 21% Oxygen, 0.9% Argon, and 0.1% other gasses
The highest temperature recorded on Earth is 58ºC while the lowest is -88ºC
The Roman goddess for Earth is Terra

string-array.name: mars
string-array.item: Mars is 221.076 kilometers from the sun
Mars is smaller than Earth and you can actually fit 7 Mars’s inside Earth
One Mars day is equivalent to 1 day and 37 minutes on Earth while one year on Mars is 697 days on Earth
Mars has 2 moons, Phobos and Deimos
Mars is terrestrial and very red
Mars’ atmosphere is 95% carbon dioxide, 3% nitrogen, 1.6% argon, and has traces of oxygen, water, and other greenhouse gasses
The temperature on Mars ranges from -140ºC to 21ºC
Mars is the Roman god of war. Greek: Ares

string-array.name: jupiter
string-array.item: Jupiter is 745.673 million km away from the sun
You can fit more than 1,300 Earths inside Jupiter
One day on Jupiter is 9 hours and 56 minutes on Earth. One year on Jupiter is 12 Earth years
Jupiter has 53 named moons and 26 other nameless moons
Jupiter is a gaseous planet
Jupiter’s atmosphere is made up of a mixture of hydrogen, helium, methane, and ammonia
The temperature on Jupiter ranges from -145ºC to 24,000ºC near the center
Jupiter is the Roman king of the gods and god of the sky and lightning. Greek: Zeus

string-array.name: saturn
string-array.item: Saturn is 95 times as massive as Earth but occupies a volume 766 times greater
One day on Saturn is 11 hours long and its orbital period is 29 Earth years
Saturn has 82 moons
Hydrogen makes up nearly all of the atmosphere, with lesser amounts of helium and much lesser quantities of methane and ammonia
Saturn is classified as a gas giant because it is almost completely made of gas
Saturn is 1.48 billion km from the sun
At the top layer of the atmosphere, the temperature ranges from minus 173 degrees Celsius to minus 113 degrees Celsius
Saturn’s associated god in Roman religion is named Saturn

string-array.name: uranus
string-array.item: Uranus has a volume which is about 63 times the volume of Earth which means that 63 Earths can fit inside Uranus
One day on Uranus is 17 hours and its orbital period is 84 Earth years
Uranus has 27 moons
Uranus has an atmosphere composed of mostly hydrogen, followed by helium and a little methane
Uranus is a gas giant
Uranus is 2.9487 billion km from the sun
The temperature of Uranus averages minus 195 degrees Celsius, according to NASA
Caelus is the associated god of Uranus in Roman religion

string-array.name: neptune
string-array.item: Neptune is almost 58 times the volume of Earth
One day on Neptune is 16 hours and a year on Neptune lasts as long as about 165 years here on Earth
Neptune has 14 moons
fact4
Neptune is a gas giant
Neptune is 4.4746 billion km from the sun
Neptune experiences temperatures that range from approximately -218 °C to -200 °C, making it the coldest planet in the Solar System
Neptune’s associated god in Roman religion is named Neptune

string-array.name: pluto
string-array.item: Pluto is only 0.59% of the volume of the Earth
A day on Pluto lasts 153 hours, or about 6 Earth days; a year on Pluto is 248 years
Pluto has 5 moons
The main constituent of Pluto’s atmosphere is molecular nitrogen, though molecules of methane and carbon monoxide have also been detected
fact5
Pluto is 5.9 billion km from the sun
The temperature on Pluto can be as cold as -226 to -240 degrees Celsius
Pluto was named after the Roman god of death
